bioghist.p: Samuel Rhoads was a naturalist, ornithologist, mammalogist, and book dealer. He collected mammal and bird specimens throughout the United States, Canada, and South America. In 1903, he published a book entitled The Mammals of Pennsylvania and New Jersey, and contributed many papers on mammals, birds, and reptiles to various zoological journals. From 1906 to 1925 he operated the Benjamin Franklin Book Store in Philadelphia, specializing in rare books on natural history. He was a founder of the Delaware Valley Ornithological Club, its Secretary, and later its President.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of manuscripts, notes, and correspondence of Samuel N. Rhoads. Manuscripts include Rhoads's writings on natural history topics such as birds and mammals; descriptions of travel in Pennsylvania, Canada, Tennessee, Florida, Texas, and Virginia; an essay on attending the first Quaker meeting at Bald Summit, an essay on literature in the home, and notes for an article on membership in the Society of Friends; and notes and drafts of his volume on the mammals of Pennsylvania and New Jersey. There is a small amount of correspondence in the collection, which includes letters from the firm that printed his Mammals, letters from colleagues who supplied him with information for that volume, and a description of his bicycle trip from Philadelphia to Bedford Springs in 1894. Other items in the collection include reprints, photos and illustrations for his Mammals volume, a copy of an Abstract of the Proceedings of the Delaware Valley Ornithological Club from 1892, photos of a hunting camp, and miscellaneous catalogs and price lists for shells and taxidermy.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
